base_note.note_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Thomas Henderson
MRN: 1005321
DOB: 08/30/1978 (46 years old)
Date: 2025-10-28
Location: University of Colorado Hospital, Aurora, CO

Attending: Dr. Rachel Kim, MD
Fellow: Dr. Ahmed Hassan, MD (PGY-5)

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Recurrent post-intubation tracheal stenosis

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same - Grade III tracheal stenosis, 8mm web-like

PROCEDURE:
1. Rigid bronchoscopy
2. Balloon dilation of tracheal stenosis
3. Biodegradable tracheal stent placement (BD-Stent, Merit Endotek)

INDICATION: 46-year-old male with history of prolonged intubation (28 days) for ARDS secondary to COVID-19 in 2021. Developed tracheal stenosis requiring multiple dilations. Has failed 3 prior balloon dilations with recurrence within 4-6 weeks. After discussion of options including T-tube, surgical resection, and biodegradable stent, patient elected for biodegradable stent trial given relatively young age and desire to avoid permanent stent or surgery.

ANESTHESIA: Total intravenous anesthesia (propofol/remifentanil)

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
Under TIVA, rigid bronchoscopy performed using 12mm Storz ventilating rigid bronchoscope. Airway anatomy:
- Subglottic region: Normal
- Tracheal stenosis: Located 2.5cm below vocal cords, approximately 8mm thick web-like stenosis narrowing the lumen to 5mm (Grade III, Myer-Cotton)
- Distal trachea and bilateral mainstem: Normal

Balloon dilation performed using 15mm x 40mm CRE balloon (Boston Scientific). Balloon inflated to 8 ATM x 60 seconds x 3 inflations with radial fracturing of the stenosis observed. Post-dilation diameter approximately 12mm.

Merit Endotek BD-Stent (18mm diameter x 30mm length, polydioxanone-based) selected based on tracheal measurements. Stent delivery system advanced through the rigid bronchoscope and deployed under direct visualization with the proximal and distal markers positioned 1cm beyond the stenosis margins. Stent expanded fully to approximately 16mm. Confirmation of good apposition to tracheal wall.

Post-procedure bronchoscopy confirmed patent airway through the stent with no evidence of stent migration. Mucosa intact with minimal bleeding from dilation site.

SPECIMENS: None

COMPLICATIONS: None

EBL: <5mL

DISPOSITION: PACU recovery, discharge home same day with post-procedure instructions. No activity restrictions. Soft diet x 24 hours.

FOLLOW-UP:
- Bronchoscopy in 8 weeks for stent assessment
- BD-Stent expected to degrade over 4-6 months
- CT airway in 3 months

Dr. Rachel Kim, MD
Dr. Ahmed Hassan, MD

registry_entry.institution_name: University of Colorado Hospital, Aurora, CO

code_rationales.31631: Tracheal stent placement (biodegradable BD-Stent) for recurrent post-intubation stenosis.
code_rationales.31630: Balloon dilation of tracheal stenosis prior to stent placement at same session, distinct therapeutic maneuver. Modifier -59 may apply per NCCI guidance.

coding_review.overall_assessment: Biodegradable stent is coded same as other airway stents. Dilation at same site prior to stenting may be separately reportable per NCCI if documented as distinct procedure.

cpt_codes.description: Bronchoscopy; with placement of tracheal stent(s)
Bronchoscopy; with tracheal/bronchial dilation or closed reduction of fracture

changes: Populated registry_entry.billing from ip_coding_billing.v2_7 for CPT codes 31631, 31630; total_work_rvu=8.17, total_rvu=13.42 (facility).

variations.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE DOCUMENTATION
============================================================

PATIENT IDENTIFICATION AND DEMOGRAPHICS
----------------------------------------
Patient: Jesse Brown
Medical Record Number: 6272942
Date of Birth: 08/30/1973
Age at Procedure: 51 years
Procedure Date: 2024-05-10

CLINICAL INDICATION AND PREOPERATIVE ASSESSMENT
----------------------------------------
The patient presented with recurrent post-intubation tracheal stenosis. Following comprehensive multidisciplinary evaluation and informed consent discussion detailing procedural risks, benefits, and alternatives, the patient elected to proceed with the proposed intervention.

PROCEDURAL METHODOLOGY AND TECHNIQUE
----------------------------------------

Airway Stent:
Airway stent deployment was executed with fluoroscopic and bronchoscopic guidance to ensure optimal positioning and mucosal apposition. 
Dilation:


INTRAPROCEDURAL FINDINGS
----------------------------------------
Detailed airway examination was performed with findings as documented in the procedural narrative.


POSTPROCEDURAL ASSESSMENT AND DISPOSITION
----------------------------------------
The procedure was completed without immediate complications. The patient demonstrated hemodynamic stability throughout and was transferred to the recovery area in satisfactory condition.

PROCEDURAL CODING DOCUMENTATION
----------------------------------------
Current Procedural Terminology Codes: 31631, 31630

This documentation has been prepared in accordance with institutional standards for procedural documentation and coding compliance.

PROCEDURE-SPECIFIC DOCUMENTATION:

variations.note_text:
On 2024-11-15, Christian Robinson, a 41-year-old male (MRN 5948849), underwent bronchoscopic evaluation for Recurrent post-intubation tracheal stenosis. The patient received General and the procedure was performed in standard fashion. The procedure included placement of Other, and dilation. 

On examination, the airways were systematically inspected. The visualized airways appeared patent without significant abnormality. The procedure was completed without immediate complications. 

The patient tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the recovery area in stable condition. Specimens obtained were sent for appropriate analysis and results will be reviewed at follow-up. The preliminary assessment is benign. 

Procedural coding: 31631, 31630.
